title: How is the temperature in which vapor pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure the boiling point of the liquid? - Quora

response.answer_text: Simply because it is the definition of the boiling point. One can change the this temperature by having a reduced atmospheric pressure. Using vacuum devices, we can boil not even heating the liquid, just reducing the pressure, of course it will go faster, if you heat.

Because until the vapour pressure reaches at least this value it is not possible for bubbles of the vapour to exist within the liquid. They will collapse. (When a kettle starts to boil bubbles of water vapour form where it is being heated and then collapse when they reach cooler water above - this makes the noise of the kettle ‘singing’ before it boils.
